passage:
(1) The Roman civilization, spanning roughly from 500 BCE to 500 CE, stands as a cornerstone of human history. Beginning in the Italian peninsula, Rome grew into a powerful empire that stretched across Europe, North Africa, and parts of Asia. Its enduring influence is seen in fields like engineering, governance, and culture, shaping societies long after its decline.

(2) Life in ancient Rome varied greatly depending on social class. The patricians, a small group of wealthy landowners, dominated politics and enjoyed luxuries, while the plebeians, the working majority, lived simpler lives as farmers, artisans, or laborers. Family was the backbone of Roman society, led by the paterfamilias, who held authority over his household. Public entertainment, such as gladiator fights and chariot races, united all classes in shared enjoyment.

(3) Roman innovations in engineering and architecture were revolutionary. They mastered concrete, building lasting structures like the Colosseum and expansive aqueducts that supplied water to cities. Their use of arches and domes allowed for grand temples and public baths, while a vast road network connected the empire, boosting trade and military efficiency.

(4) Beyond construction, Rome's contributions to law and language were profound. The Twelve Tables established early legal principles, later expanded into the Corpus Juris Civilis, influencing modern justice systems. Latin, Rome's language, gave rise to the Romance languages and enriched scientific vocabulary. Writers like Virgil and Cicero left literary works that remain studied today.

(5) Rome's legacy echoes in today's world. Its republican government inspired democratic ideals, while its architectural techniques influence modern design. Infrastructure like roads and sanitation systems set urban planning standards. The adoption of Christianity in Rome's later years also shaped global religion and culture, cementing its historical impact.

questions.question: She __________ to the store when it started raining.
If I __________ more time, I would learn Italian.
The teacher asked us __________ the assignment by tomorrow.
The movies that we watched __________ very exciting.
Neither the students nor the teacher __________ late yesterday.
I wish I __________ how to play the guitar.
The room __________ cleaned every day.
__________ her busy schedule, she still found time to help.
He runs so fast that he __________ everyone in the race.
By next month, I __________ here for five years.
She asked me where __________ last weekend.
This is the best book I __________ read.
They __________ to the meeting if they had known about it.
The instructions were clear, __________ nobody understood them.
I enjoy __________ to music in my free time.
The manager is looking for someone __________ of managing a team.
'I can't find my keys,' she said. She said that she __________ her keys.
The project __________ completed by the deadline.
'Do you want to join us?' he asked. He asked if I __________ to join them.
The flight was __________ due to heavy fog.
She's very tired because she __________ all day.
I need to __________ my presentation before the meeting.
'How long have you lived here?' She asked me how long __________ there.
The teacher explained the homework __________ everyone understood.
He's not very good __________ solving problems quickly.
What is a synonym for 'rapid'?
The opposite of 'doubtful' is:
'Eager' most nearly means:
The __________ of the experiment surprised the scientists.
She has a __________ interest in ancient history.
The noise was so __________ that I couldn't sleep.

The __________ of the story teaches a valuable lesson.

What is the main idea of the passage?

options.A: Rome was the largest empire in ancient history.
options.B: Roman innovations and culture continue to influence modern society.
options.C: Life in ancient Rome was difficult for all people except patricians.
options.D: The Romans were primarily known for their military conquests.

questions.question: According to paragraph 2, what role did the paterfamilias play?

options.A: He governed the city of Rome.
options.B: He led the family with authority.
options.C: He trained gladiators for public events.

questions.question: Which innovation is NOT mentioned in paragraph 3?
What does the passage say about the Twelve Tables?

options.A: They were Rome's first written laws.
options.B: They were written by Virgil and Cicero.

questions.question: In paragraph 1, the word "cornerstone" most nearly means:
What can be inferred about Roman roads from paragraph 3?

options.A: They were built only for military use.
options.B: They helped improve trade across the empire.
options.C: They were made entirely of concrete and steel.
options.D: They were destroyed after Rome's fall.

questions.question: According to paragraph 5, Rome influenced modern society through:
What is one example of Roman entertainment mentioned in paragraph 2?
The author suggests that Roman innovations were significant because:

options.A: They were unique to Rome and never copied by others.
options.B: They have a lasting impact on today's world.
options.C: They were completed quickly and cheaply.
options.D: They were only useful during Rome's time.

questions.question: Which paragraph discusses Roman contributions to language?
